text:
SPEAKER: There are
so many examples

of going into new sectors
for a diversified business
such as yours.

And thinking about how you adapt
to the new environment and then
take that learning back--

JAIME AUGUSTO ZOBEL:
Yeah, and then
spread it out across the group.

And during that period,
the '90s, when I took over,

we also developed a
whole new sector, again,

related to laying out
infrastructure for the country.

This time it was in the
telecommunications field.
This was different.

Our country was dominated by
one major private company.

They pretty much controlled
the whole telecommunication
industry.

And again, under President
Ramos' government,

they decided to
liberalize the sector

and encourage
investment to come in.

So we had very little knowledge
about the telecommunications
sector at the time, if none.

And it was not the
telecommunications sector
you see today.

We had a small investment
in a telex company.

And so we had a
little bit of a--
but we had a minority stake.
We weren't running the business.

The old conglomerate IT&T used
to have a significant stake
there.

And then one day, IT&T
came to us and said,

look, we're thinking of selling
out the business globally,

which is quite extraordinary,
If you think about it.

That's IT&T that had
a global footprint
in telecommunications.

They sold pretty much
everything they had at the time

when telecommunications
took off.
But that's a whole other story.

It has nothing to do with us,
but probably worthy of study.

Anyway, they said to us,
you need a good partner
and sell out with us.
Let's just sell out together.

And I'd just taken over the
helm at the time, early '90s.

And I made a pitch
with our board

that this is an area that
was going to grow and change.
And technology was shifting.

And that I'd like to take a
major stake in the business
and recommended it.
It was a tough process.

Number one, because when you're
going through a liberalization,

there are a lot
of forces at play

to try to prevent an
industry from changing,

from a structure which had
been there for 50, 60 years.

But it was the political
will of the government that
created the right framework.

Then, we had to find
a technical partner.

We had very little
knowledge about the area.

And we were lucky,
after a number

of tries, to find ourselves with
the Singapore telecom group,

who have been
incredible partners.

I didn't want to tie up with
a supplier or a company that
made equipment.

I wanted to tie up with
a service operator.

And when I looked
around, I said,

in Asia, I said, one of the
leading figures in this space

and one of the best standards
being set in service operations
were with the Singapore group.

So I packed my bags and
headed to Singapore.

I didn't know anyone at the
time, called up some bankers,
said, introduce me to people.

I'd like to meet the Temasek
group and the Singapore group.

And at the beginning, they
were deeply concerned.

They said, there is no
framework for this industry.

There is no policy
framework, there's no--

I said, I realize that,
but there's an opportunity.

He said, yeah, no, we understand
that there's an opportunity.

But no, we're not
ready for this.
So it took a while.

And there was a
lot of discussion
backwards and forwards.

And we didn't really have a
clear framework for investment.

And the Singaporeans,
by nature, quite the--
SPEAKER: They like a framework.

JAIME AUGUSTO ZOBEL: They
like clean frameworks, which,
of course, Singapore has.

But I said, you know, this
is an emerging market.
It's evolving.
Why don't we do this together?
We'll work with the government.
And we'll work on this.

And after a while,
it took them a while.

And maybe that was
another key lesson.

We threw our hat in
the ring together.

We reached an agreement on
how to invest in this company.

But we had to do
many things jointly.

Number one, we had a telex
company, not a telecom company.

So we had to get a
national franchise.

We had to go to our
Congress or Senate.

That took two or three
years to process.

And then once we
had it, we then had

to start evolving
the technology.

We had to decide what
technology to use.

The beginnings of
mobile were happening.
The US had a standard.
The Europeans had a standard.
I didn't know which way to go.

We talked to the Singaporeans
and they said-- at the time,

they said the US standard
is from an engineering
point of view.
It's a very good standard.

But the Europeans have really
built the standard that it's--

that works very well
across national boundaries,
the GSM standard at the time.

And they said
let's go with that.
